org.dellroad.muxable.simple

Class SimpleMuxableChannel

  • java.lang.Object
    • org.dellroad.stuff.net.SelectorSupport
      • org.dellroad.muxable.simple.SimpleMuxableChannel
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    Closeable, AutoCloseable, Channel, MuxableChannel

    public class SimpleMuxableChannel
extends SelectorSupport
implements MuxableChannel
    An implementation of the MuxableChannel interface that multiplexes nested channels over a single underlying ByteChannel (or ReadableByteChannel, WritableByteChannel pair) using a simple framing scheme.

    The nested channel data and NestedChannelRequests share the same underlying "real" channel, so any one left unread for too long can block all the others. This implementation only guarantees that "senseless" deadlock won't happen (see MuxableChannel).

    Java NIO

    This is a Java NIO based implementation. The underlying channel(s) must be SelectableChannels and (for now) use the default SelectorProvider. The nested channels returned by this class will use same SelectorProvider as the underlying channel(s).

    Because an internal service thread is created, instances must be explicitly start()'d before use and stop()'d when no longer needed. When this instance is stop()'d, the underlying channel(s) are closed.

    Invoking close() on this instance has the same effect as invoking stop().

    Instances are thread safe.

    • Method Detail

      • newNestedChannelRequest

        public NestedChannelRequest newNestedChannelRequest(ByteBuffer requestData,
                                                    Directions directions)
                                             throws IOException
        Description copied from interface: MuxableChannel
        Create a new nested channel, or pair of nested channels, scoped to this instance.

        The remote side will be notified by the appearance of a corresponding NestedChannelRequest in the queue returned by MuxableChannel.getNestedChannelRequests() (with the input and output channels reversed, of course). The delivery of requests on the remote side is guaranteed to preserve order (but only to the extent order is well-defined on the sending side, i.e., there is a "happens before" relationship).

        Specified by:
        newNestedChannelRequest in interface MuxableChannel
        Parameters:
        requestData - data to supply to the remote side (via NestedChannelRequest.getRequestData())
        directions - which of input and/or output to create
        Returns:
        the newly created nested channel(s)
        Throws:
        IOException - if an I/O error occurs

      • getNestedChannelRequests

        public BlockingQueue<NestedChannelRequest> getNestedChannelRequests()
        Description copied from interface: MuxableChannel
        Access the queue of incoming NestedChannelRequests initiated from the remote side.

        Each NestedChannelRequest corresponds to a remote invocation of newNestedChannelRequest(). Moreover, the order of requests is preserved.

        Because the remote side can close a nested channel at any time, it is possible that a NestedChannelRequest is already closed by the time it's pulled from this queue. In this case, the input and output channels will throw IOException on first access.

        Note: no special change happens to the returned BlockingQueue once this instance is closed; instead, new reqeusts simply stop appearing. Therefore, after closing this instance, any thread(s) that are blocked polling for new data may need to be woken up via Thread.interrupt().

        Specified by:
        getNestedChannelRequests in interface MuxableChannel
        Returns:
        queue of NestedChannelRequest initiated from the remote side
